patterns: when are student mentoring guys open
responses: The student mentoring team consists of Alina, Elisa, Merri, Zahra, and Fariburz. They are responsible for mentoring COSMOS students. You can reach them via email at cs-mentoring@uos.de. Office hours for everyone are on Thursdays from 09:00 to 12:00. For international students, Zahra and Fariburz are available on Thursdays from 12:00 to 13:00, online only.

patterns: consultation hours for the examination office
how to contact the examination office
responses: The examination office is responsible for the administration of examinations, including the creation of performance overviews, certificates, and diplomas. For examination-related matters, please contact Carla Högemann, Kelwin Maethner, or Julia Reuter at Wachsbleiche 27, 49090 Osnabrück. You can reach them during consultation hours or via email at pacogsci@uni-osnabrueck.de. Note: When contacting by email, provide a clear subject line.

If you have a problem with the study program, planning your studies, brainstorming about courses, finishing your bachelor's, writing your thesis, or need assistance with any academic matter, we recommend contacting the study mentoring team. They are available to help you with these issues.

patterns: I want to apply for the CogSci program
Can you help me with the CogSci program application?
How do I apply for the Cognitive Science program?
responses:
You can apply for the Cognitive Science program through the Universität Osnabrück website. Universität Osnabrück offers several degrees in Cognitive Science:

- BSc in Cognitive Science: A bachelor's degree program focusing on the interdisciplinary study of the mind and its processes.
- MSc in Cognitive Science: A master's degree program providing advanced knowledge and research opportunities in cognitive science.
- Cognitive Computing MSc: A specialized master's degree program focusing on the intersection of cognitive science and computing technologies.

For more details and application procedures, please visit the Universität Osnabrück website.

patterns: How can I contact the program coordinator?
responses: You can contact the program coordinator and dean of studies, Dr. Dr. Gregor Hörzer, for specific questions regarding the programs of the teaching unit Cognitive Science. Dr. Hörzer holds office hours on Mondays from 10-12 a.m. in room 50/E04, which is located right next to the examination office. To schedule an appointment, please register in Stud.IP for the course 'Consultation Hour Dean of Studies Cognitive Science' and book an appointment via the 'Terminvergabe'/ 'Date allocation' tab. When booking an appointment, please briefly state the issue you would like to discuss.

patterns: contact for semester abroad in Osnabrück
responses: During your studies, you can participate in a mandatory semester abroad at another institution. For more information about semester abroad opportunities in Osnabrück, please contact us at ikw-eras@uos.de.

patterns: responsible for administrative and research issues
responses: For administrative and research issues, please contact Dr. Tobias Thelen at office@ikw.uni-osnabrueck.de.

patterns: get IT support as a student or employee
responses: For IT support, students and employees can direct their questions to ikwadmin@uni-osnabrueck.de.

patterns: what are the courses offered in summer semester 24?
what are the courses in IKW?
can you tell me the courses available in IKW?
can you tell me the branches available in IKW?
responses:
Here is the course schedule for the summer term 2024:

1.
    Cognitive (Neuro-)Psychology:
  • Introduction to Cognitive (Neuro-)Psychology- Cognitive Science in the Anthropocene
  • Episodic Cognition
  • Language: Evolution, its use and social interaction
  • Trends in Language and Brain Research
  • Emotion and Motivation

2.
    Neuroscience
  • Sensory Physiology
  • Action and Cognition: Motor System (Lecture)
  • Action and Cognition: Visual System (Seminar)
  • Decoding Neuronal Activity
  • Journal Club 'Spatial Cognition'
  • Quest
  • Reading Group on Integrative Systems Approaches in Cognitive Computational Neuroscience
  • Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience
  • Biologisches Experimentalpraktikum
  • Emotion and Motivation
  • Biopsychologie

3.
    Neuroinformatics
  • Machine Learning
  • Neurodynamics
  • Decoding Neuronal Activity
  • Modelling of Synaptic Plasticity
  • Advanced Computer Vision
  • Deep Neural Network Analysis

4.
    (Computational) Linguistics
  • Introduction to Computational Linguistics
  • Grounding LLMs in the Physical World
  • Experimenting with Language
  • Trends in Language and Brain Research

5.
    Artificial Intelligence
  • Introduction to AI and Logic Programming
  • Formal Models for Analyzing and Creating Music
  • Reading Course: Computational Cognitive Science
  • Computational Creativity in Natural Language Processing
  • Machine Learning
  • Advanced Computer Vision
  • Grounding LLMs in the Physical World
  • Deep Neural Network Analysis

6.
    Philosophy
  • Philosophy for Cognitive Science
  • Neuroscience and Philosophy: The Libet Experiments
  • Rationalism and Empiricism: Two Paradigms in Cognitive Science and their Philosophical Origins in Descartes and Hume (Part 1)
  • Rationalism and Empiricism: Two Paradigms in Cognitive Science and their Philosophical Origins in Descartes and Hume (Part 2)
  • Introduction to the Ethics of AI (Lecture + Discussion Group)
  • Current Topics in the Ethics of Information Technology
  • Neuere Beiträge zur deutschsprachigen Debatte über Willensfreiheit
  • Personal Identity, Norms, and Ethics: The Philosophy of Derek Parfit
  • Consciousness, Science, and the Universe
  • Introduction to the Philosophy of Mind (Intensive Course)
  • Philosophy of Emotions (Intensive Course)

7.
    Methods of Cognitive Science
  • Anleitung zum wissenschaftlichen Arbeiten
  • Writing like a Language Scientist
  • Basic Programming in Python
  • Scientific Programming in Python
  • Topics in Math for Cognitive Science

8.
    Informatik
  • Advanced Computer Vision
  • Machine Learning
  • Einführung in die Algorithmik

9.
    Mathematik
  • Mathematics for Cognitive Science
  • Analysis II
  • Lineare Algebra II
  • Mathematik für Anwender II

10.
    Study Project
  • Data Ethics Outreach Lab
  • Automatic Music Transcription (Part I)
  • The secret lives of adjectives - The Psycholinguistics of Adjective Use (Part III)
  • Dyadic eye tracking in virtual reality to investigate visual interaction (Part II)
  • Human-A and EEG (Part II)
  • Spatial Navigation supported by AI (Part I)
  • Emergent Behaviors in a Multi-Agent System with Reinforcement Learning (Part IV)
  • The Mentality of Apes by Wolfgang Köhler: One century later (Part IV)
  • Computing with Spikes (Part I)
  • DreamGuard: A Web Application for restful Nights (Part I)

11.
    Interdisciplinary Courses
  • The secret lives of adjectives: The Psycholinguistics of adjective use (Part II) (Begleitseminar)
  • Spatial Navigation supported by AI (Part I) (Begleitseminar)
  • Emergent Behaviors in a Multi-Agent System with Reinforcement Learning (Part IV) (Begleitseminar)
  • Computing with Spikes (Part I) (Begleitseminar)
  • Decoding Neuronal Activity
  • Projects at the Intersection of Neuroscience and Machine Learning
  • Practical Cognitive Science Communication
  • Neuroscience and Philosophy: The Libet Experiments
  • Quest
  • Enhancing AI through Hybrid Data Sets
  • Lab Rotation

12.
    Electives
  • Reading Club Affectivity
  • Language and Communication Colloquium
  • Colloquium „Computer Vision“
  • Scientific Programming in Python
  • Basic Programming in Python
  • Writing like a Language Scientist

13.
    Integrative Mandatory Element in the Electives Bachelor
  • None

14.
    Integrative Optional Element in the Electives Bachelor
  • Anleitung zum wissenschaftlichen Arbeiten

15.
    PhD students
  • Soft Skills for PhD students

Please note that this information is based on the course schedule as of Feb 8, 2024 and is subject to change. It's advisable to confirm with the university for the most up-to-date information.

patterns: what is the address of university
responses: The university buildings are mainly located in the city center and in the Westerberg district, which is close to the city centre. Most CogSci lectures take place at Westerberg campus here

patterns: how far is accommodation from college
responses: The first place to go to find student housing is the Accommodation Office, run by the Studentenwerk. Besides operating the dormitories, they can also help you find private housing. There are about 1700 dormitory rooms available. Types of housing available range from single rooms to shared housing and apartments for families. If you wish to rent a room in the student dormitories, you should send your application for accommodation as early as possible. Please note: Exchange students from partner universities apply for accommodation in the student dormitories through the International Office!.For more information visit here
